Critical Reflection

Religion and the Gender Violence Database: Reflections, Difficulties, and Remaining Gaps

by

Reilly Brady

While working on the Gender Violence Database throughout 2023, I focused on the ways in which religion and religious identity can shape experiences of gender-based violence as well as paths of healing for survivors. During my previous work with the Gender Violence Database, I noticed an emerging awareness of the specific religious contexts that can shape experiences of gender violence; in the social work journals I had previously focused on, this translated to a need for culturally-sensitive approaches in therapy and other social work fields. However, there seemed to be a general lack of scholarship within gender violence-focused journals addressing religious contexts of gender-based violence both in terms of culturally-specific approaches and concerning broader implications about religious institutions serving as forces of harm as well as as spaces for healing for survivors.

I discovered the Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion in my search for scholarship discussing gender violence and religion together. I worked through each issue from the start of the journal in 1985, tagging articles discussing dynamics of gender-based violence in religious contexts. The most common type of article addressing gender violence in this journal was short-form pieces or reflections written by scholars addressing a specific topic or theme, such as teaching dynamics of gender violence and religion in the university classroom. The next most common category was scholarship analyzing gender violence within religious texts, often taking into consideration the difficulties in applying today’s gender violence terminology to historical contexts in which that terminology did not yet exist. Many scholars published in the Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion also applied a theoretical framework or discourse analysis to examine a particular dynamic of gender violence within religious contexts. A few articles brought in research discussing the experiences of survivors of gender-based violence but rarely followed a qualitative approach with methods such as interviews and/or surveys, instead drawing from other sources such as past observations and research or their own experiences.

Within analyses of gender violence in religious texts came challenges with the very practice of assigning tags –– which is also essentially assigning terms, especially difficult to do when reading about historical contexts in which the words I used to tag articles didn’t yet exist or were otherwise not understood or applicable in the discourses of the time. Part of the tagging process requires drawing our own conclusions about what tags most accurately reflect the content of an article –– for example, I might recognize an article as discussing topics related to the "structural" tag, even if the author doesn't explicitly use the term "structural" in their article. However, where this becomes particularly tricky is in analyses of historical texts. Because the term "intimate partner violence," for example, did not exist when a particular religious text was written, is it possible to tag an article analyzing that text with that term? Figuring out what terms to use is something the authors of these articles struggle with themselves, such as one author defining what they are discussing as "intimate partner violence" in the abstract but examining their use of that term deeper in the actual text of the article. As another example, how would choosing either the tag “rape” (defined in the tagging guide as “non-consensual sex perpetrated by someone the victim/survivor does not know”) or the tag “acquaintance” (defined in our guide as “non-consenual sexual acts between people who know each other”) ever fully and adequately reflect the dynamics of sexual violence in a journal article about sexual slavery in the Bible? In that case, discerning “stranger” rape versus “acquaintance” rape felt not only impossible, but inane and reductive to the actual dynamics at play. And yet, wrestling with each tag to ensure that it is categorized correctly to be the most helpful for those using the database is part of the process, as difficult and impossible that process can feel.

Amidst these difficulties, some tags often applied well to various articles discussing religion and gender-based violence. Common tags used for articles within the Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion included “creed,” defined in our schema as “structural violence in religious or ritualized beliefs, practices, and organizations,” and “faith,” defined in our schema as “initiatives implemented by religious organizations and/or according to faith-based goals and/or values.” These tags went beyond simply defining which religious context an article referenced, representing larger themes and structural issues that emerged within these analyses of religion and gender-based violence.

What remains largely under-researched in the Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion, as well as other current scholarship on gender violence in general, is the voices of survivors themselves discussing the dynamics that emerge within their specific religious contexts, whether that be to analyze structures silencing and shaming survivors or to highlight culturally important contexts that may arise for survivors in their healing processes, among other vital and under-researched topics. I do not mean to single out this particular journal –– these voices are needed in scholarship across disciplines. My experiences in the past few years tagging articles within various journals focusing on gender-based violence reveal that bringing in dynamics of religion within this scholarship remains rare. A journal focusing on gender violence that does not include voices of survivors in religious contexts or largely ignores any analysis of gender violence in religious institutions misses specific contexts of power and control that can potentially shape survivors’ experiences in significant and all-encompassing ways. To further research dynamics of gender-based violence such as spiritual abuse as well as to better understand how religious identity may shape how survivors conceptualize their experiences and approach healing and resilience, scholarship on gender violence must consider the role religion plays in survivors’ experiences.
